issue.title: Community Shepherd
issue.body:
* Be present in *#packit:fedora.im*, *#packit:libera.chat*, and *Packit gchat* channel to answer community questions or ping some other team member to help answer those questions.

 * Keep an eye on incoming issues opened by our users. The unprocessed issues can be found in [the `new` column of our Kanban board](https://github.com/orgs/packit/projects/7/views/1). React to them trying to clarify them, if needed, or ask the team to help give a meaningful reaction to them. Use appropriate labels and move the issue to the `backlog` column once the issue is clear.

 * Help new users trying to enable Packit Service to configure their repositories.

 * Watch out for incoming issues in [github.com/packit/notifications](https://github.com/packit/notifications/issues) if someone needs help with the automatic approval process. Delete old, unanswered issues, or the ones which look like spam.

 * Watch [auto-packit-shared-infra mailing list](https://groups.google.com/a/redhat.com/g/auto-packit-shared-infra/membership) for planned cluster upgrades. Once one is scheduled:
     * Create a new [status post](https://github.com/packit/status)
     * Write to the *#packit channel* to inform everyone about the possible service disruption during the upgrade
     * Work with the *Chief of Monitors* to handle sentry alerts that may happen during the upgrade

issue.title: CI Hacker
issue.body:
This is a role card for the one responsible throughout the sprint for keeping the CI green, that is to look for and drive the resolution of systematic CI failures.

It can happen that a CI system has an outage. For problems related to Zuul, please reach out to the team at `#rhos-ops` internal IRC channel.

issue.title: Release Responsible
issue.body:
Check if there are changes worth releasing for all our RPM-packaged projects: [packit](https://github.com/packit/packit), [ogr](https://github.com/packit/ogr), [specfile](https://github.com/packit/specfile)

(`packit` is used as an example below)

 * Run [Prepare a new release](https://github.com/packit/packit/actions/workflows/prepare-release.yml) workflow via `Run workflow` button: choose `main` branch and type the correct version number for the new release. In a while, you should see the action running and creating a pull request in the repository. 
 * Review the created PR - you can ask other team members to help you with changelog grammar if needed. You can check out the PR locally, update it and push it back to the PR.
 * Merge the pull request once you're fine with the content (and there are no pending review requests).
 * The merge of the PR should trigger [an action](https://github.com/packit/packit/actions/workflows/do-release.yml) that creates a draft release.
 *  You should be able to find the draft release as a first release in the [releases list](https://github.com/packit/packit/releases). Edit the release, make sure the content is correct and then publish the release by clicking `Publish release`.
 * Make sure the package is [uploaded](https://github.com/packit/packit/actions/workflows/pypi-publish.yml) to [PyPI](https://pypi.org/project/packitos/#history)
 * Check (wait a few minutes) & merge [PRs in dist-git](https://src.fedoraproject.org/rpms/packit/pull-requests) created by packit: merge those created by the *stage instance* and close the ones created by the *production instance*. (But check that both services proposed the same set of changes.)
 * Wait a few minutes and verify that [RPMs are built in Koji](https://koji.fedoraproject.org/koji/packageinfo?packageID=28291)
 * Wait a bit and verify that [updates have been created in Bodhi](https://bodhi.fedoraproject.org/updates/?search=packit)
 * Celebrate another release 🚀🎉

issue.title: Kanban Lead
issue.body:
* Watch Jira board and [GitHub project](https://github.com/orgs/packit/projects/7) are up to date

 * [x] Announce the new roles on Monday in the chat.
 * Be a moderator for stand-ups, refinements, architecture and retrospective meetings.
 * If there is a longer meeting, make sure that there is a clear structure of the meeting so that it is easier for remotees to follow.
 * Stand-ups:
   * Think of a question and ask it at the beginning
   * Run standup
     * Remind people to describe their cards/work when providing an update on their progress.
   * Ask about discussion topics after everyone presents their update
   * [x] On Monday, ask about [blocked cards](https://github.com/orgs/packit/projects/7/views/16), [in-progress cards](https://github.com/orgs/packit/projects/7/views/6), [urgent cards](https://github.com/orgs/packit/projects/7/views/5?filterQuery=-status%3Adone+-status%3Aready-for-release+-status%3Ain-review+-label%3AEPIC+-status%3A%22in-progress+%5B10%5D%22++-status%3Areleased+-label%3Aroles+-label%3Ablocked++due-date%3A%3C%40today%2B14days) and priorities in the Refinement column - make sure that everything is up to date!
 * [ ] If it's an odd week (check with `date '+%V'`)
   * [ ] Create a retro board ([use this template in Miro](https://miro.com/app/dashboard/?tpTemplate=uXjVON1po0U%3D&isCustom=true&invite_link_id=798126687786)).
   * [ ] Copy actions/improvements from previous retro board, so we can check whether we did everything we wanted to.
   * [ ] Attach the link to the retrospective event in our Google calendar.
   * [ ] On retro ask about EPICs and whether we're working on the right ones
 * Manual: [An overview of how Packit Team kanbanz](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1THB9k2v3NtsvWZuKGohrpOnFkmlwboJQfkrCnp-ltdI/edit#heading=h.vjznozqqmakq)

issue.title: Chief of Monitors
issue.body:
Watch [Sentry](https://sentry.io/organizations/red-hat-it/issues/?project=1767823) for issues:

 * Fix recurring alerts
   * Deploy fixes to production for issues that cause major disruption or complete downtime
   * Verify no alerts are being triggered any more
 * More complicated issues should be brought to the team and prioritized correctly.
 * Clean all the past alerts so we have easy to navigate dashboard
 * Link github and sentry issues

React to alerts arriving through email and check the [SLO monitoring page](http://metrics.osci.redhat.com/d/VXwH27XMk/rhel-infrastructure-and-service-health?orgId=1) (Packit section) and respond to the email so others know what is happening.

Watch our other two Grafana dashboards as well:
* [Celery Monitoring](http://metrics.osci.redhat.com/d/3OBI1flGz/celery-monitoring-with-flower?orgId=1&from=now-24h&to=now&refresh=10s)
* [Packit Monitoring](http://metrics.osci.redhat.com/d/iuAkAaWMk/packit?orgId=1)

issue.title: Service Guru
issue.body:
Every Monday:
 * [ ] (On stand-up) Check with the team whether deploying new changes from *main* branches is safe.
 * [ ] Make sure stage deployment is OK, check:
   * [Openshift cluster](https://console-openshift-console.apps.auto-prod.gi0n.p1.openshiftapps.com/k8s/cluster/projects/packit-stg)
   * [Sentry](https://sentry.io/organizations/red-hat-0p/issues/?environment=stg&project=1767823)
   * [Dashboard](https://dashboard.stg.packit.dev/)

If all is fine and things are good to go:
 * [ ] Create a [blog post](https://packit.dev/posts) about what's been changed in packit & packit-service *main* branches since their *stable* branch. Use [`scripts/move_stable.py github-query`](https://github.com/packit/deployment/blob/main/scripts/move_stable.py) to get a link to all the PRs from the past week which are marked to have release notes. You can copy those for a start, and check with other team members to make sure nothing was left out. You can also use the blogpost template provided by [`make move-stable`](https://github.com/packit/deployment/blob/main/Makefile). A blog post should meet the following requirements:
   * This is meant to be read by general public - make it easy to read for everyone.
   * Focus on new features, notable bug fixes, documentation updates, UX improvements.
   * Don't talk about internal things (e.g. most ogr/specfile changes), refactoring, CI changes etc.
   * Write it in a way so that people with a little knowledge of the project can get a clue what is the change about:
     * **NO**: packit's behaviour in dealing with spec files was improved
     * **YES**: packit can now find a spec file inside a bottle of rum which is very handy if you're thirsty
  * [ ] Move content from *main* branches to *stable* branches.
    * From a clone of the [deployment](https://github.com/packit/deployment) repo run `make move-stable` command. Your local ssh keys have to be associated with your github user to be able to use this script.
    * Go to the Actions tab ([example](https://github.com/packit/packit-service/actions) of the respective repos) and make sure the images from the stable branches are built & [pushed to Quay.io](https://quay.io/organization/packit?tab=logs).
  * If there were any changes in the [Kubernetes/Openshift objects](https://github.com/packit/deployment/tree/main/openshift) or in the [vault](https://vault.bitwarden.com)/`Packit`/`! Changelog !` that have not been already applied to prod (ask the author of the change), do so with `DEPLOYMENT=prod make deploy`.
  * ~~If you're doing this *AFTER* new images have already been built (see previous point) you should run `DEPLOYMENT=prod make import-images` first (or after), to avoid possible `Error: ImagePullBackOff`.~~

Monday night & Tuesday morning:
 * Newer images are [automatically imported from Quay.io](https://github.com/packit/deployment/blob/main/docs/continuous-deployment.md) and pods are recreated from the new images.

On Tuesday:
 * [ ] Make sure [*prod*](https://console-openshift-console.apps.auto-prod.gi0n.p1.openshiftapps.com/k8s/cluster/projects/packit-prod) runs as expected - [revert the deployment](https://github.com/packit/deployment/blob/main/docs/continuous-deployment.md#reverting-to-older-deploymentrevisionimage) if all jobs fail or there is significant regression in the functionality.
 * [ ] Merge/publish your blog post.

release.body:
- Fixed an issue due to which the repository was never searched for a specfile if 'specfile_path' was not specified, and 'specfile_path' was always set to '<repo_name>.spec'. (#1758)
- Packit is now able to generate automatic Bodhi update notes including a changelog diff since the latest stable build of a package. (#1747)

issue.title: Community Shepherd
issue.body:
* Be present in *#packit:fedora.im*, *#packit:libera.chat*, and *Packit gchat* channel to answer community questions or ping some other team member to help answer those questions.

 * Keep an eye on incoming issues opened by our users. The unprocessed issues can be found in [the `new` column of our Kanban board](https://github.com/orgs/packit/projects/7/views/1). React to them trying to clarify them, if needed, or ask the team to help give a meaningful reaction to them. Use appropriate labels and move the issue to the `backlog` column once the issue is clear.

 * Help new users trying to enable Packit Service to configure their repositories.

 * Watch out for incoming issues in [github.com/packit/notifications](https://github.com/packit/notifications/issues) if someone needs help with the automatic approval process. Delete old, unanswered issues, or the ones which look like spam.

 * Watch [auto-packit-shared-infra mailing list](https://groups.google.com/a/redhat.com/g/auto-packit-shared-infra/membership) for planned cluster upgrades. Once one is scheduled:
     * Create a new [status post](https://github.com/packit/status)
     * Write to the *#packit channel* to inform everyone about the possible service disruption during the upgrade
     * Work with the *Chief of Monitors* to handle sentry alerts that may happen during the upgrade

issue.title: CI Hacker
issue.body:
This is a role card for the one responsible throughout the sprint for keeping the CI green, that is to look for and drive the resolution of systematic CI failures.

It can happen that a CI system has an outage. For problems related to Zuul, please reach out to the team at `#rhos-ops` internal IRC channel.

issue.title: Release Responsible
issue.body:
Check if there are changes worth releasing for all our RPM-packaged projects: [packit](https://github.com/packit/packit), [ogr](https://github.com/packit/ogr), [specfile](https://github.com/packit/specfile)

(`packit` is used as an example below)

 * Run [Prepare a new release](https://github.com/packit/packit/actions/workflows/prepare-release.yml) workflow via `Run workflow` button: choose `main` branch and type the correct version number for the new release. In a while, you should see the action running and creating a pull request in the repository. 
 * Review the created PR - you can ask other team members to help you with changelog grammar if needed. You can check out the PR locally, update it and push it back to the PR.
 * Merge the pull request once you're fine with the content (and there are no pending review requests).
 * The merge of the PR should trigger [an action](https://github.com/packit/packit/actions/workflows/do-release.yml) that creates a draft release.
 *  You should be able to find the draft release as a first release in the [releases list](https://github.com/packit/packit/releases). Edit the release, make sure the content is correct and then publish the release by clicking `Publish release`.
 * Make sure the package is [uploaded](https://github.com/packit/packit/actions/workflows/pypi-publish.yml) to [PyPI](https://pypi.org/project/packitos/#history)
 * Check (wait a few minutes) & merge [PRs in dist-git](https://src.fedoraproject.org/rpms/packit/pull-requests) created by packit: merge those created by the *stage instance* and close the ones created by the *production instance*. (But check that both services proposed the same set of changes.)
 * Wait a few minutes and verify that [RPMs are built in Koji](https://koji.fedoraproject.org/koji/packageinfo?packageID=28291)
 * Wait a bit and verify that [updates have been created in Bodhi](https://bodhi.fedoraproject.org/updates/?search=packit)
 * Celebrate another release 🚀🎉

issue.title: Kanban Lead
issue.body:
* Watch Jira board and [GitHub project](https://github.com/orgs/packit/projects/7) are up to date

 * [x] Announce the new roles on Monday in the chat.
 * Be a moderator for stand-ups, refinements, architecture and retrospective meetings.
 * If there is a longer meeting, make sure that there is a clear structure of the meeting so that it is easier for remotees to follow.
 * Stand-ups:
   * Think of a question and ask it at the beginning
   * Run standup
     * Remind people to describe their cards/work when providing an update on their progress.
   * Ask about discussion topics after everyone presents their update
   * [x] On Monday, ask about [blocked cards](https://github.com/orgs/packit/projects/7/views/16), [in-progress cards](https://github.com/orgs/packit/projects/7/views/6), [urgent cards](https://github.com/orgs/packit/projects/7/views/5?filterQuery=-status%3Adone+-status%3Aready-for-release+-status%3Ain-review+-label%3AEPIC+-status%3A%22in-progress+%5B10%5D%22++-status%3Areleased+-label%3Aroles+-label%3Ablocked++due-date%3A%3C%40today%2B14days) and priorities in the Refinement column - make sure that everything is up to date!
 * [ ] If it's an odd week (check with `date '+%V'`)
   * [ ] Create a retro board ([use this template in Miro](https://miro.com/app/dashboard/?tpTemplate=uXjVON1po0U%3D&isCustom=true&invite_link_id=798126687786)).
   * [ ] Copy actions/improvements from previous retro board, so we can check whether we did everything we wanted to.
   * [ ] Attach the link to the retrospective event in our Google calendar.
   * [ ] On retro ask about EPICs and whether we're working on the right ones
 * Manual: [An overview of how Packit Team kanbanz](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1THB9k2v3NtsvWZuKGohrpOnFkmlwboJQfkrCnp-ltdI/edit#heading=h.vjznozqqmakq)

issue.title: Chief of Monitors
issue.body:
Watch [Sentry](https://sentry.io/organizations/red-hat-it/issues/?project=1767823) for issues:

 * Fix recurring alerts
   * Deploy fixes to production for issues that cause major disruption or complete downtime
   * Verify no alerts are being triggered any more
 * More complicated issues should be brought to the team and prioritized correctly.
 * Clean all the past alerts so we have easy to navigate dashboard
 * Link github and sentry issues

React to alerts arriving through email and check the [SLO monitoring page](http://metrics.osci.redhat.com/d/VXwH27XMk/rhel-infrastructure-and-service-health?orgId=1) (Packit section) and respond to the email so others know what is happening.

Watch our other two Grafana dashboards as well:
* [Celery Monitoring](http://metrics.osci.redhat.com/d/3OBI1flGz/celery-monitoring-with-flower?orgId=1&from=now-24h&to=now&refresh=10s)
* [Packit Monitoring](http://metrics.osci.redhat.com/d/iuAkAaWMk/packit?orgId=1)

React to alerts arriving through email and check the [SLO monitoring page](http://metrics.osci.redhat.com/d/VXwH27XMk/rhel-infrastructure-and-service-health?orgId=1) (Packit section) and respond to the email so others know what is happening.

Watch our other two Grafana dashboards as well:
* [Celery Monitoring](http://metrics.osci.redhat.com/d/3OBI1flGz/celery-monitoring-with-flower?orgId=1&from=now-24h&to=now&refresh=10s)
* [Packit Monitoring](http://metrics.osci.redhat.com/d/iuAkAaWMk/packit?orgId=1)

issue.title: Service Guru
issue.body:
Every Monday:
 * [ ] (On stand-up) Check with the team whether deploying new changes from *main* branches is safe.
 * [ ] Make sure stage deployment is OK, check:
   * [Openshift cluster](https://console-openshift-console.apps.auto-prod.gi0n.p1.openshiftapps.com/k8s/cluster/projects/packit-stg)
   * [Sentry](https://sentry.io/organizations/red-hat-0p/issues/?environment=stg&project=1767823)
   * [Dashboard](https://dashboard.stg.packit.dev/)

If all is fine and things are good to go:
 * [ ] Create a [blog post](https://packit.dev/posts) about what's been changed in packit & packit-service *main* branches since their *stable* branch. Use [`scripts/move_stable.py github-query`](https://github.com/packit/deployment/blob/main/scripts/move_stable.py) to get a link to all the PRs from the past week which are marked to have release notes. You can copy those for a start, and check with other team members to make sure nothing was left out. You can also use the blogpost template provided by [`make move-stable`](https://github.com/packit/deployment/blob/main/Makefile). A blog post should meet the following requirements:
   * This is meant to be read by general public - make it easy to read for everyone.
   * Focus on new features, notable bug fixes, documentation updates, UX improvements.
   * Don't talk about internal things (e.g. most ogr/specfile changes), refactoring, CI changes etc.
   * Write it in a way so that people with a little knowledge of the project can get a clue what is the change about:
     * **NO**: packit's behaviour in dealing with spec files was improved
     * **YES**: packit can now find a spec file inside a bottle of rum which is very handy if you're thirsty
  * [ ] Move content from *main* branches to *stable* branches.
    * From a clone of the [deployment](https://github.com/packit/deployment) repo run `make move-stable` command. Your local ssh keys have to be associated with your github user to be able to use this script.
    * Go to the Actions tab ([example](https://github.com/packit/packit-service/actions) of the respective repos) and make sure the images from the stable branches are built & [pushed to Quay.io](https://quay.io/organization/packit?tab=logs).
  * If there were any changes in the [Kubernetes/Openshift objects](https://github.com/packit/deployment/tree/main/openshift) or in the [vault](https://vault.bitwarden.com)/`Packit`/`! Changelog !` that have not been already applied to prod (ask the author of the change), do so with `DEPLOYMENT=prod make deploy`.
  * ~~If you're doing this *AFTER* new images have already been built (see previous point) you should run `DEPLOYMENT=prod make import-images` first (or after), to avoid possible `Error: ImagePullBackOff`.~~

Monday night & Tuesday morning:
 * Newer images are [automatically imported from Quay.io](https://github.com/packit/deployment/blob/main/docs/continuous-deployment.md) and pods are recreated from the new images.

On Tuesday:
 * [ ] Make sure [*prod*](https://console-openshift-console.apps.auto-prod.gi0n.p1.openshiftapps.com/k8s/cluster/projects/packit-prod) runs as expected - [revert the deployment](https://github.com/packit/deployment/blob/main/docs/continuous-deployment.md#reverting-to-older-deploymentrevisionimage) if all jobs fail or there is significant regression in the functionality.
 * [ ] Merge/publish your blog post.

issue.title: Community Shepherd
issue.body:
* Be present in *#packit:fedora.im*, *#packit:libera.chat*, and *Packit gchat* channel to answer community questions or ping some other team member to help answer those questions.

 * Keep an eye on incoming issues opened by our users. The unprocessed issues can be found in [the `new` column of our Kanban board](https://github.com/orgs/packit/projects/7/views/1). React to them trying to clarify them, if needed, or ask the team to help give a meaningful reaction to them. Use appropriate labels and move the issue to the `backlog` column once the issue is clear.

 * Help new users trying to enable Packit Service to configure their repositories.

 * Watch out for incoming issues in [github.com/packit/notifications](https://github.com/packit/notifications/issues) if someone needs help with the automatic approval process. Delete old, unanswered issues, or the ones which look like spam.

 * Watch [auto-packit-shared-infra mailing list](https://groups.google.com/a/redhat.com/g/auto-packit-shared-infra/membership) for planned cluster upgrades. Once one is scheduled:
     * Create a new [status post](https://github.com/packit/status)
     * Write to the *#packit channel* to inform everyone about the possible service disruption during the upgrade
     * Work with the *Chief of Monitors* to handle sentry alerts that may happen during the upgrade

issue.title: CI Hacker
issue.body:
This is a role card for the one responsible throughout the sprint for keeping the CI green, that is to look for and drive the resolution of systematic CI failures.

It can happen that a CI system has an outage. For problems related to Zuul, please reach out to the team at `#rhos-ops` internal IRC channel.

issue.title: Release Responsible
issue.body:
Check if there are changes worth releasing for all our RPM-packaged projects: [packit](https://github.com/packit/packit), [ogr](https://github.com/packit/ogr), [specfile](https://github.com/packit/specfile)

(`packit` is used as an example below)

 * Run [Prepare a new release](https://github.com/packit/packit/actions/workflows/prepare-release.yml) workflow via `Run workflow` button: choose `main` branch and type the correct version number for the new release. In a while, you should see the action running and creating a pull request in the repository. 
 * Review the created PR - you can ask other team members to help you with changelog grammar if needed. You can check out the PR locally, update it and push it back to the PR.
 * Merge the pull request once you're fine with the content (and there are no pending review requests).
 * The merge of the PR should trigger [an action](https://github.com/packit/packit/actions/workflows/do-release.yml) that creates a draft release.
 *  You should be able to find the draft release as a first release in the [releases list](https://github.com/packit/packit/releases). Edit the release, make sure the content is correct and then publish the release by clicking `Publish release`.
 * Make sure the package is [uploaded](https://github.com/packit/packit/actions/workflows/pypi-publish.yml) to [PyPI](https://pypi.org/project/packitos/#history)
 * Check (wait a few minutes) & merge [PRs in dist-git](https://src.fedoraproject.org/rpms/packit/pull-requests) created by packit: merge those created by the *stage instance* and close the ones created by the *production instance*. (But check that both services proposed the same set of changes.)
 * Wait a few minutes and verify that [RPMs are built in Koji](https://koji.fedoraproject.org/koji/packageinfo?packageID=28291)
 * Wait a bit and verify that [updates have been created in Bodhi](https://bodhi.fedoraproject.org/updates/?search=packit)
 * Celebrate another release 🚀🎉

issue.title: Kanban Lead
issue.body:
* Watch Jira board and [GitHub project](https://github.com/orgs/packit/projects/7) are up to date

 * [x] Announce the new roles on Monday in the chat.
 * Be a moderator for stand-ups, refinements, architecture and retrospective meetings.
 * If there is a longer meeting, make sure that there is a clear structure of the meeting so that it is easier for remotees to follow.
 * Stand-ups:
   * Think of a question and ask it at the beginning
   * Run standup
     * Remind people to describe their cards/work when providing an update on their progress.
   * Ask about discussion topics after everyone presents their update
   * [x] On Monday, ask about [blocked cards](https://github.com/orgs/packit/projects/7/views/16), [in-progress cards](https://github.com/orgs/packit/projects/7/views/6), [urgent cards](https://github.com/orgs/packit/projects/7/views/5?filterQuery=-status%3Adone+-status%3Aready-for-release+-status%3Ain-review+-label%3AEPIC+-status%3A%22in-progress+%5B10%5D%22++-status%3Areleased+-label%3Aroles+-label%3Ablocked++due-date%3A%3C%40today%2B14days) and priorities in the Refinement column - make sure that everything is up to date!
 * [ ] If it's an odd week (check with `date '+%V'`)
   * [ ] Create a retro board ([use this template in Miro](https://miro.com/app/dashboard/?tpTemplate=uXjVON1po0U%3D&isCustom=true&invite_link_id=798126687786)).
   * [ ] Copy actions/improvements from previous retro board, so we can check whether we did everything we wanted to.
   * [ ] Attach the link to the retrospective event in our Google calendar.
   * [ ] On retro ask about EPICs and whether we're working on the right ones
 * Manual: [An overview of how Packit Team kanbanz](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1THB9k2v3NtsvWZuKGohrpOnFkmlwboJQfkrCnp-ltdI/edit#heading=h.vjznozqqmakq)

issue.title: Chief of Monitors
issue.body:
Watch [Sentry](https://sentry.io/organizations/red-hat-it/issues/?project=1767823) for issues:

 * Fix recurring alerts
   * Deploy fixes to production for issues that cause major disruption or complete downtime
   * Verify no alerts are being triggered any more
 * More complicated issues should be brought to the team and prioritized correctly.
 * Clean all the past alerts so we have easy to navigate dashboard
 * Link github and sentry issues

React to alerts arriving through email and check the [SLO monitoring page](http://metrics.osci.redhat.com/d/VXwH27XMk/rhel-infrastructure-and-service-health?orgId=1) (Packit section) and respond to the email so others know what is happening.

Watch our other two Grafana dashboards as well:
* [Celery Monitoring](http://metrics.osci.redhat.com/d/3OBI1flGz/celery-monitoring-with-flower?orgId=1&from=now-24h&to=now&refresh=10s)
* [Packit Monitoring](http://metrics.osci.redhat.com/d/iuAkAaWMk/packit?orgId=1)

issue.title: Community Shepherd
issue.body:
* Be present in *#packit:fedora.im*, *#packit:libera.chat*, and *Packit gchat* channel to answer community questions or ping some other team member to help answer those questions.

 * Keep an eye on incoming issues opened by our users. The unprocessed issues can be found in [the `new` column of our Kanban board](https://github.com/orgs/packit/projects/7/views/1). React to them trying to clarify them, if needed, or ask the team to help give a meaningful reaction to them. Use appropriate labels and move the issue to the `backlog` column once the issue is clear.

 * Help new users trying to enable Packit Service to configure their repositories.

 * Watch out for incoming issues in [github.com/packit/notifications](https://github.com/packit/notifications/issues) if someone needs help with the automatic approval process. Delete old, unanswered issues, or the ones which look like spam.

 * Watch [auto-packit-shared-infra mailing list](https://groups.google.com/a/redhat.com/g/auto-packit-shared-infra/membership) for planned cluster upgrades. Once one is scheduled:
     * Create a new [status post](https://github.com/packit/status)
     * Write to the *#packit channel* to inform everyone about the possible service disruption during the upgrade
     * Work with the *Chief of Monitors* to handle sentry alerts that may happen during the upgrade

issue.title: CI Hacker
issue.body:
This is a role card for the one responsible throughout the sprint for keeping the CI green, that is to look for and drive the resolution of systematic CI failures.

It can happen that a CI system has an outage. For problems related to Zuul, please reach out to the team at `#rhos-ops` internal IRC channel.

issue.title: Release Responsible
issue.body:
Check if there are changes worth releasing for all our RPM-packaged projects: [packit](https://github.com/packit/packit), [ogr](https://github.com/packit/ogr), [specfile](https://github.com/packit/specfile)

(`packit` is used as an example below)

 * Run [Prepare a new release](https://github.com/packit/packit/actions/workflows/prepare-release.yml) workflow via `Run workflow` button: choose `main` branch and type the correct version number for the new release. In a while, you should see the action running and creating a pull request in the repository. 
 * Review the created PR - you can ask other team members to help you with changelog grammar if needed. You can check out the PR locally, update it and push it back to the PR.
 * Merge the pull request once you're fine with the content (and there are no pending review requests).
 * The merge of the PR should trigger [an action](https://github.com/packit/packit/actions/workflows/do-release.yml) that creates a draft release.
 *  You should be able to find the draft release as a first release in the [releases list](https://github.com/packit/packit/releases). Edit the release, make sure the content is correct and then publish the release by clicking `Publish release`.
 * Make sure the package is [uploaded](https://github.com/packit/packit/actions/workflows/pypi-publish.yml) to [PyPI](https://pypi.org/project/packitos/#history)
 * Check (wait a few minutes) & merge [PRs in dist-git](https://src.fedoraproject.org/rpms/packit/pull-requests) created by packit: merge those created by the *stage instance* and close the ones created by the *production instance*. (But check that both services proposed the same set of changes.)
 * Wait a few minutes and verify that [RPMs are built in Koji](https://koji.fedoraproject.org/koji/packageinfo?packageID=28291)
 * Wait a bit and verify that [updates have been created in Bodhi](https://bodhi.fedoraproject.org/updates/?search=packit)
 * Celebrate another release 🚀🎉

issue.title: Service Guru
issue.body:
Every Monday:
 * [ ] (On stand-up) Check with the team whether deploying new changes from *main* branches is safe.
 * [ ] Make sure stage deployment is OK, check:
   * [Openshift cluster](https://console-openshift-console.apps.auto-prod.gi0n.p1.openshiftapps.com/k8s/cluster/projects/packit-stg)
   * [Sentry](https://sentry.io/organizations/red-hat-0p/issues/?environment=stg&project=1767823)
   * [Dashboard](https://dashboard.stg.packit.dev/)

If all is fine and things are good to go:
 * [ ] Create a [blog post](https://packit.dev/posts) about what's been changed in packit & packit-service *main* branches since their *stable* branch. Use [`scripts/move_stable.py github-query`](https://github.com/packit/deployment/blob/main/scripts/move_stable.py) to get a link to all the PRs from the past week which are marked to have release notes. You can copy those for a start, and check with other team members to make sure nothing was left out. You can also use the blogpost template provided by [`make move-stable`](https://github.com/packit/deployment/blob/main/Makefile). A blog post should meet the following requirements:
   * This is meant to be read by general public - make it easy to read for everyone.
   * Focus on new features, notable bug fixes, documentation updates, UX improvements.
   * Don't talk about internal things (e.g. most ogr/specfile changes), refactoring, CI changes etc.
   * Write it in a way so that people with a little knowledge of the project can get a clue what is the change about:
     * **NO**: packit's behaviour in dealing with spec files was improved
     * **YES**: packit can now find a spec file inside a bottle of rum which is very handy if you're thirsty
  * [ ] Move content from *main* branches to *stable* branches.
    * From a clone of the [deployment](https://github.com/packit/deployment) repo run `make move-stable` command. Your local ssh keys have to be associated with your github user to be able to use this script.
    * Go to the Actions tab ([example](https://github.com/packit/packit-service/actions) of the respective repos) and make sure the images from the stable branches are built & [pushed to Quay.io](https://quay.io/organization/packit?tab=logs).
  * If there were any changes in the [Kubernetes/Openshift objects](https://github.com/packit/deployment/tree/main/openshift) or in the [vault](https://vault.bitwarden.com)/`Packit`/`! Changelog !` that have not been already applied to prod (ask the author of the change), do so with `DEPLOYMENT=prod make deploy`.
  * ~~If you're doing this *AFTER* new images have already been built (see previous point) you should run `DEPLOYMENT=prod make import-images` first (or after), to avoid possible `Error: ImagePullBackOff`.~~

Monday night & Tuesday morning:
 * Newer images are [automatically imported from Quay.io](https://github.com/packit/deployment/blob/main/docs/continuous-deployment.md) and pods are recreated from the new images.

On Tuesday:
 * [ ] Make sure [*prod*](https://console-openshift-console.apps.auto-prod.gi0n.p1.openshiftapps.com/k8s/cluster/projects/packit-prod) runs as expected - [revert the deployment](https://github.com/packit/deployment/blob/main/docs/continuous-deployment.md#reverting-to-older-deploymentrevisionimage) if all jobs fail or there is significant regression in the functionality.
 * [ ] Merge/publish your blog post.

release.body:
- Fixed an issue due to which the repository was never searched for a specfile if 'specfile_path' was not specified, and 'specfile_path' was always set to '<repo_name>.spec'. (#1758)
- Packit is now able to generate automatic Bodhi update notes including a changelog diff since the latest stable build of a package. (#1747)
